bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, March 3, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] discusses a fever outbreak in Ecuador. He weighs the evidence for and against a diagnosis of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, March 3, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Guayaquil
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
March 3, 1923.
Dr. F. F. Russell,
Director of Public Health Laboratories,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I have, in a measure, answered the question in your letter of
March 2nd. in my Memorandum to the I. H. B. of the same date, enclosing
nearly the same letter from Pareja.
There is this in continuation to be said:

1/ The report of the cases is too defective to allow much of a
conclusion to be based on it.

That all save one occurred in seranos and all occurred in what
one might call the endemic yellow fever zone of Ecuador might seem sus-
picious of yellow fever. On the other hand, there is nothing to show
how long these people have lived in that zone and thus we can formu-
late no idea whether they have been immunized (by previous attack of
yellow fever).

There was yellow fever at Santa Rosita also in 1918 or '19, whence
Peru is believed to have derived it, but this place has not been habit-
ually infected.

2/ We do not know whether these cases (ictero-hemorrhagica)
have only occurred in this Stegomyia infested area. The statement a-
bout Dr. Arcos at Quito rather implies the contrary, but it is only an
implication. Of course, if he is finding the same disease on the high-
lands of Ecuador it would negative, for them at least, the diagnosis of
yellow fever.

3/ The fact that, from the grouping of the cases, there is no
evidence of one leading to (infecting) another, if reasonable investi-
gation has been made, would go far to negative yellow fever. If these
reports were made in good faith--there is no questioning Pareja's in-
tegrity--and search has been made for secondary cases, I would count the
diagnosis of yellow fever negatived. It may be, however, that some
Ecuadoreans would be loth to report yellow fever on account of the com-
mercial damage that would be done. Americans, as you know, have felt
the same way in the U. S.

I am inclined to think--I say this with some reserve, however,
that a number of physicians are looking for ictero-hemorrhagica and
therefor seeing it.

I am enclosing a copy of a second letter from Dr. Pareja. I
have Carbos' reprint.

In the hospital cases, I wonder if the first date given is the
date of attack or that of entrance to hospital? I presume the date
of attack, but the 6th. case rather implies the latter. Naturally, any
certain deduction from the duration of the dying cases is dependent on
this knowledge.

If it be yellow fever or any communicable disease it should show
up very soon--indeed should have done so before, because no Stegomyia
work has, I think, been done in the out-lying places--Milagro: Bucay etc.-
and one would suppose that since 1919 they would have accumulated a cer-
tain number of susceptible people.
